author: BigBeard
title: Friendly & Helpful Workers
body: From the moment I entered the car park until I said my last goodbye everybody working to delivery the vaccination programme were so friendly, helpful & professional. I feel a tremendous amount of national pride in being a part of this & those helping to delivery it should be immensely proud!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: alphaff59
title: Fantastic nursing team
body:
Ward 205 Royal Infirmary Edinburgh is managed to a high level of professionalism by Katie, Jen and Kay who as well as managing the ward also dispense daily medications to patients helped by Lisa, Finnart, Brian, Laura, Maria, Elsie and others.  
Also part of this fantastic nursing team are Eric, Paul, Lauren, Stacey and Lauren to name but a few, also helping this ward more pleasurable are Eileen and Louise who regularly bring tea and biscuits.

links.id: very well looked after and cared for

author: Jam999
title: A total knee replacement
body:
I was welcomed into the ambulatory care department of Forth Valley Royal Hospital at 8 am and over the next couple of hours had a chat with some of the people who would be involved in my procedure. They took great care to tell me what I should expect. When the time arrived I walked along to the theatre with my surgeon and anaesthetic staff where we settled into the anaesthetic room. Everyone was very chatty, and friendly, managing to keep any nerves at bay. I had a spinal anaesthetic, with nerve block and local injections so there was no chance of feeling any pain. Once I was settled in a comfortable position, I went to sleep, knowing no more until I woke up in the recovery room, with lots of people to keep me company until it was time to move to the ward which would continue my care.  
The National Treatment Centre, a COVID free ward, looked after me with great compassion, making sure I was pain-free at all times and always had everything I might need. The next day, after a visit from the physiotherapists and my lovely surgeon, I was allowed to go home, just 36 hours after I had arrived. My stay was short but very sweet and I am delighted to be rid of the pain which has been curtailing my activities for years.

author: Cmm86
title: Open, honest and friendly
body: A really open, honest and friendly consultation that pre-empted a lot of my questions and concerns but also made me feel I could ask any additional questions. Felt like a proper conversation rather than one-sided information being given and I really appreciated that in terms of going forward with my treatment decisions.

title: Terrible
body:
Came to this hospital with an appointment arranged over the phone. The symptoms I had I’d been told by my doctor previously that if I was experiencing them that I needed to seek urgent medical attention.
The A&E staff were rude, continued having a personal conversation while I was in front of them waiting to talk, and I was told they couldn’t guarantee someone would see me, even though I had come at the arranged appointment time...
I had an initial assessment and then was told to go back to A&E waiting room and wait to be called. The waiting time was 6 hours.
I’m sorry but this is not how appointments work.
This hospital was out of the way for me and I only came to this one because I could be ‘seen’ at that time.
Awful experience - particularly when patients are genuinely concerned about their condition.
Oh and the vending machine didn’t work so I couldn’t even get water for the 6 hour wait.

title: First class Treatment - Crap NHS communication…
body: Treatment, Care, all absolutely great. Trying to communicate to Amersham Hospital a Nightmare. The auto connect Translated "Dermatology" as "Haematology" and offered hospitals other than Amersham - transfer to operator rang for ten minutes before I gave up. On the third occasion I was told (Autovoice) that staff busy and the hours when I could ring. All of this is not a new experience!!!  Whoever sorts out the automatic systems needs to extract the digit and design/provide systems which assist busy staff and long-suffering patients.

author: Millerhill12
title: Useless phone appointments
body: Five months waiting for ENT. 3 growths in my Mouth diagnosed through the phone as abscess none of the GPs have seen me, ENT do not respond. Constant pain and no help at all! I find this to be ignorant.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Unworkable booking system
body: The phone booking system is disfunctional.  Waiting times and position in the queue oscillates wildly.  Today it seems the system is not even accepting calls.   Please fix the awful booking system.  There have been complaints so far.

title: Excellent service
body: No problem arranging a vaccination. Very efficient, calm and professional. All explained and no dramas.

title: Very poor Dr , patient relationship
body: Just had my Dr's face to face appointment, this is after nearly a month waiting. I found an experiment very uncomfortable. I am not expecting any polite interaction, but I found the whole session very unprofessional and unnecessarily rude. Couldn't wait for me leave the room, the Dr got up and opened a door for me leave, I had to ask, if we have finished!!. I felt that I was kicked out.

title: Excellent Caring Practice
body:
I am very grateful to belong to Old Church Surgery.
The Surgery is becoming busier and busier yet the staff and Doctors remain caring and compassionate.
I telephoned about my concerns and had to wait in the telephone queue.
I appreciated there are many, many people who have medical concerns and need attention.
The receptionist was courteous and helpful and though I could imagine she was busy, she treated me with respect and as if 'I were the first patient' that day.
She understood my concerns, discussed the possible ways forward and arranged for me to be called back.
I was later called, my anxieties discussed and action taken to resolve my concerns.
This is typical of the Courtesy and care of The Old Church Surgery.
Yes. I am honoured and grateful to belong to this Surgery.

title: Wonderful with my elderly mum
body: Just took my acutely confused 92 year old mum to see this GP after speaking to them this morning. The GP was absolutely fantastic with her.  So kind and considerate and did a very thorough examination of her. Gave me options also of what I would like to happen and I agreed with the doctor about what we wanted to happen next.  I can't praise this Doctor highly enough and just wish I was able to say their name.  Thank you

title: Great staff
body: I've had 4 appointments in the last week, each one dead on time, no waiting, all staff were lovely, very impressed! Thank you!

title: Brillant Experience!!!
body: I recently got referred to physiotherapy for arthritis in my knees and hips which has been very beneficial to me.I really look forward to going to each session.I just wanted to say thank you.may the good work continue.

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: A great C-Section Experience!
body: A great experience right from before birth right up to the day of birth! On the day that my daughter was born, the team looking after me where great! Everyone was truly professional and I would highly recommend maternity services at BGH!

readBy.name: Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent care
body: Having felt extremely unwell, and worried, spoke with a practice nurse, who was very helpful and reassuring. I attended the surgery that very morning. Just wanted to say thank you.

author: Chl2002
title: Communication with family members
body:
A family member has been admitted numerous amounts of times to Good Hope Hospital over time, for various reasons due to his physical health.  
Every time we ring up to ask how he's doing and if they've found anything wrong, we get shrugged off and told that they don't know, and to call back the next day. When we call back in the morning and the afternoon the next day, we are told the same thing.  
There has also been numerous times where he has been discharged we feel still in bad condition, resulting in readmission.  
I have also called ward 16 recently and I am still shrugged off as the workers don't know what's wrong with him or if he's ok, again just telling us to call the next day. This is appalling as it was suggested by paramedics that he could potentially have a serious health problem that had been undiagnosed!  
I highly believe this needs to be sorted asap not just for me but for other patients' worried family and friends.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

author: Brillopad Head
title: My Covid-19 vaccinations
body: I have now had both Covid-19 vaccinations, the first at the Ulster Hospital and the second at the SSE Arena. I am full of praise for all the personnel involved in this process. Everyone I encountered was professional, friendly and helpful. You would not have thought they were carrying out the same tasks repeatedly, as I was treated as if I was the first person to arrive that day. A huge thanks to everyone involved.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Srow
title: Kind, caring and considerate
body:
An ambulance was sent out to my grandmother. From the moment they arrived at the house their professionalism and manners towards my grandmother was outstanding. We as a family want to particular thank this crew, one member on the crew was called Gary, and unsure of his other colleagues name but we want to thank them for transferring granny safely to hospital.  
Keep up the good work.

author: Cromwell
title: My husband died unexpectedly
body:
We were on holiday near Thirsk . We had an enjoyable first 4 days then on the Tuesday Andrew suffered a heart attack . (He was fit healthy man normal weight he hadn’t seen a doctor for 13 years)  
The ambulance men settled him taking him to York hospital.  
Tests revealed a lot of heart problems. Andrew was moved to Coronary Care Unit. Two evenings later the Thursday Andrew had a cardiac arrest and although resuscitated he died several hours later.  
Having not been allowed to visit ( Covid rules ) on the Wednesday I was grateful to be allowed to spend those last 3 hours quietly with Andrew as his life drained away.  
I was kept informed at every stage.  
I would like to thank the kind paramedics ,the A&E staff and the CCU especially Andrew’s doctors and nurse Hannah who cared for him in such a quiet,gentle and respectful way in those last hours .

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: pepperwc53
title: My experience of virtual visiting
body:
I have had many virtual visits with both Craigavon and daisy hill hospitals, I found them extremely efficient when I have asked for a certain time I have always been accommodated. You are sent a text to explain the procedure which is very helpful, the operator who takes your call is friendly, pleasant and very helpful explaining everything that will happen.
In the text message you receive it is explained that your time is allocated and you may have to wait up to 30 mins before your call is made to you in case something has happened in which case you may consider your call cancelled and you will be contacted the next day, which is understandable, this has never happened to me and I have never had to wait more than 20 minutes past my call time.
I find this a great service during this very uncertain time and at least we get to speak to our loved ones who need to know that family still care and can still get to see them

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Karin K
title: I was well looked after
body:
I have recently been discharged from RAH, after major bowel surgery. From the minute I walked into the hospital until my discharge the care I received was second to none. I was admitted to ward 29, then taken down to Theatre for my surgery, this was the start of fantastic process, even with face masks and PPE, I really felt the staff were so warm and caring, and for sure professional.  
Back in the ward I was well looked after, all my needs met and more. My partner was able to visit which was so helpful to my recovery. I can not say enough about the fantastic care I received. For sure Mr Renwick my surgeon was superb, I felt at every point of my time in the hospital. Even my discharge was completed with such ease as I was really worried about having to walk out, but again this was seen to. I can not thank everybody enough from the Doctors, Nurses and all the support staff, including the auxiliary staff who rarely get a mention.

author: SKTroon
title: Fantastic from start to finish!
body:
Having had my hip operation cancelled twice in the past year due to Covid, it went ahead last week at Ayr Hospital. From the receptionist on arrival, to the nurses, auxilliaries, surgeon and anaesthetist I couldn’t fault anyone. They were fantastic at their individual roles coming together perfectly.  
I wanted to say thank you as people are all too quick to criticise. For the staff involved in my care at station 16, nothing was too much trouble which made my experience much more pleasant than it might have been.

author: SkitteeKatt
title: Importance of personal connection during a time when “a personal touch” seems impossible.
body:
The pandemic has, for many, made one-to-one contact somewhat inaccessible. It is often difficult to feel included on a personal level on platforms such as Zoom - particularly with larger audiences. I have had considerable difficulties with this myself, which is why for some time I refused to include myself in group sessions held online.  
Having been convinced by Adrian one day to “feel the fear, but do it anyway” I reluctantly attended one of his Zoom sessions. Looking back, I only wish I'd done so sooner. I cannot fathom how somebody can dominate, and captivate, such a sizeable (and at times, rowdy!) audience. His delivery is dynamic and engrossing - the session content seems structured without being scripted, and there is always opportunity for personal interaction. Above all - and most importantly for me - his humanistic, attentive approach makes every subject matter relatable. In turn, I have been inspired to apply what I have learned through him to better my life (and behaviours) significantly. With thanks to Adrian for both the initial nudge and the running of these sessions, I am understanding my worth and my capabilities. No longer bound by my past or by unnecessary guilt. I owe my sobriety to the whole of CGL, but my personal growth to him.

author: Dusty T
title: My 80 year old Dads Visit to Day Surgery. FVRH
body: Took my Dad for a biopsy in FVRH. Appointment was on time and Nurse   called David that met us in reception was very professional, went over COVID questions and made my Dad very at ease. This carried on in the room with David and Lynda who were both treating him and everything was explained very clear. 10 out of 10 experience.

author: virgosk95
title: Face timing my 88 year old mother in Craigavon hospital
body:
What an excellent and comforting service  
My deaf mother was on 3 north for 3 days before I knew about service but once I was told we got it set up very very easily  
Lady called Sylvia was excellent so kind and friendly and calmed my nerves very quickly as I had been upset at not being able to book a slot to visit mum  
Young man who brought the iPad to mum was also lovely and I heard him chatting to her  
Picture was so clear and mum who is very hard of hearing could hear some of what I said and other family members could at least show their faces and wave to her  
I just wish I had known of service earlier as booking visits is still difficult  
Thanks to everyone involved in this service

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: mumoftwoboys
title: Knowledgeable and professional
body: I had my Covid injection, felt fine the next day but the following day had terrible palpitations and heart fluttering whilst watching TV. Phoned ambulance. Paramedics arrived pretty quickly and monitoring showed I was in fast Atrial Fibrillation. Heart rate at that point was high, rising further by the time I reached A&E at the RAH. Blood pressure was also raised. Taken to Coronary Care Unit for cardioversion and monitoring. The staff, including student nurses were just brilliant. So knowledgeable and professional. They couldn’t do enough for me and did every single task with a smile on their faces. The catering staff and domestics also seemed to be happy in their jobs. Was a pleasure to see. Eventually my heart rate settled and I was allowed home the following afternoon. I’d just like to say a massive thanks to all involved in my care and wish all the students the very best in their futures. Great nurses, all of them.

author: montrose30
title: Very friendly and helpful
body: My 85 year mother received great service from the Dundee enhanced community support acute team. The nurses /doctor were all very friendly and helpfull could not fault them they made a big difference to my mother just a pity it had to stop. 10 out of 10 thank you very much.

author: Concerned110
title: Communication
body:
In my fathers admission to hospital, I found communication with the ward to be extremely difficult . First I phoned switch board, then I got transferred to the patient liaison, they took my details and said the ward would get back to me. I contacted patient liaison again at an hour later and was asked to be patient. After another hour I still had heard nothing I was extremely worried and contacted patient liaison again  
Eventually I got to speak to a nurse who looked after my dad.  
I was communicating on behalf of all my family to save all of us phoning the ward.  
It nearly took 3 hours for me to hear how my dad was today. My dad is 90 years old and ill. So those three hours were spent in a state of anxiety.  
Why did it take so long!!  
Why could my dad's nurse not give a quick two second message after she tended to my dad. Just to let us all know he slept well. Will update you later with a call when not so busy.  
We were left worried for nearly 3 hours. I don’t want this to happen to anyone else.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: NC4677899
title: Excellent service
body: Truly excellent service. Very well planned and orchestrated. Loved the positivity of the volunteers who calmed those of us that were nervous. Very professional set up and makes you even more proud of our NHS. Well done all.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: woo62
title: Bowel cancer diagnosis, op, care & recovery
body:
I was diagnosed with a cancerous tumour in the stigmoid area of the bowel in December 2020 having mentioned to my GP that streaks of blood had appeared in my stools. A rectal exam hadn't found anything and that was followed by a colonoscopy which revealed the tumour. I was assigned 2 wonderful support nurses, Claire and Chrissie who were my 'go to'for any information and concerns. A colonography revealed that, thankfully, there was only one tumour which was still contained in the bowel and was operable.  
My op took place in January 2021 and was successful (yay!). I met my surgeon and anaesthatist beforehand who fully explained what would happen. I should add that I recieved information at every point of my journey, I never felt ignored or under-valued but fully supported, no question was ever considered to be unnecessary. I had a fast-track recovery in hospital, again the staff were so supportive and helpful and was back home 4 days after a major operation. I had been told that it would be a 4 to 6 week recovery and was contacted by someone on the oncology team every day for the first 2 weeks. I was encouraged to be active, slowly with small steps to begin with. I enjoy walking so that wasn't a problem and each day I gave myself a goal of walking a little further. It was tiring and frustrating but eventually I got used to the "no bending, no stretching " rule!  
4 weeks into my recovery and I was starting to feel so much better and more positive mentally too. I recieved a phone call from one of my support nurses who gave me a round-up of the histology report. As well as removing the tumour. They had removed 22 lymph nodes, 2 if which showed signs of cancerous cells, so the news was that I was to go onto 3 months of chemotherapy, 4 cycles in total just to make sure they got it all. In an instant I had gone from recovery mode back to preparation mode. I knew it was another step forward to full recovery but in my heart I felt I'd taken several steps back.  
I met my oncologist, who fully explained the chemical combination I would be taking and a whole range of potential side effects (some were scary, but you do need to have all the information). It was a lot to take in, but it made me feel better...I prefer working on facts rather than 'if, buts and maybe. Plus there was always Claire or Chrissie to talk to if I had any concerns. I also had a 24 hour emergency phone number that I could ring if I had any concerns regarding side effects I was experiencing and yes, I have used it and yes, they too were wonderfully understanding and supportive.  
I have been fortunate enough to experience the lesser of the side effects (I have wondered if that is because the cancer was caught early), including pins and needles in my fingertips and throat cramps, both resulting from a sensitivity to temperature changes. Easily coped with if you remember to wear gloves when handling cold things like metal pans and cutlery or going into the fridge or freezer. Oh, and run the hot tap when you go to the loo at 3am! You only forget to do that once! The only pain I experienced was a reaction to the drug which is the one you get through the drip at the start of each cycle. This was relieved by the insertion of a PICC line which fed the drug directly into my larger vein.  
My only other problem was that my bone marrow reacted badly to the chemo and a couple of times I had to wait a week to two longer to enable my white cell count to recover so I could begin the next cycle. Frustrating but nothing to be done, it was explained to me that it wasnt anything I was or wasn't doing.  
Now I'm in my final cycle. I have spent 2 hours at the Headlands Unit at Treliske (again, brilliantly supportive, friendly staff) on the drip and have rung the bell that celebrates your last visit and recovery. I am on my last 2 weeks of chemo tablets at home. Its tiring for the first week but each day it becomes a little easier and I'm looking forward to a camping trip with the family at the end if June, something I wasn't sure I was going to be able to attend.  
I look back at the last 5 months and it all feels a little surreal. The one thing that does feel real is all the help and support I have had from every member of staff at Treliske who has been on my journey with me. It doesnt finish now either; I will go onto a 5 year surveillance program which includes further CT scans and a colonoscopy. In the meantime I'm looking forward to enjoying new things in my life as well as getting out to meet up with family and friends eventually...pandemic permitting of course!

author: Penfoldio
title: Very professional
body:
Had both vaccinations at Parkgate Community Centre Rosyth. Felt fine, after both, just a little tired, for a day or so. It was a bit sore, (getting it) the second time, but the 'sore arm' has not been as sore as the Flu vaccination I receive every year.  
The staff and nurses were excellent, very professional as well as being Human!  
Thank you very much.

author: Joe L
title: Being able to see my mother who is waiting on tests to be done
body: I was grateful to be able to see her and talk to her. The sound was good and seeing her made me feel more content. she seemed very glad to see her family as during civil restrictions she could feel on her own. The booking process with Sylvia was very smooth and the text message reassuring. Thank you

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Amethyst Lee
title: Very happy
body: I came to the centre for my second covid jab. Although there was a bit of a line and I had to wait in the cold, the line went rather quickly. We were given temperature checks and had a little hand sanitiser. From there we were ushered in to get our details checked and given a number. This number was used to call our turn for the jab. I had a wonderful volunteer who listened to my worries and helped me understand what to look for if any of the side effects arise. After my jab, I had a little wait to make sure I was ok before I could go home. Very happy with how I was treated!

author: WPete
title: Undiagnosed TIA
body:
I believe I suffered a TIA 1 week after the COVID-19 vaccine.  
The ambulance did not attend until the day after. Was taken to Wigan Infirmary and given an head x-ray presenting with a seizure.  
There had been a head injury 3 months prior but was presenting with a seizure in early April.  
I am left with lots of pain all down my left side and need a proper diagnosis.  
I have asked my GP through the website to refer me to TIA clinic but I am getting no response.  
I was referred to the Walton Centre for possible Epilepsy which was ruled out. I am now waiting on an MRI scan. I am 100% sure I had a Transient Ischaemic Attack but can't get it investigated at TIA which is stopping me from getting the right treatment.  
I am starting taking asprin and have stopped smoking.  
I can't get anyone to listen to me and investigate things for what they are and not for what they are not.

readBy.name: North West Boroughs Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

title: Fobbed off
body: I had an issue with my shoulder almost 5 years ago that caused massive pain and has been ongoing since. I went to the doctors many times in the first few years and was constantly told I’d just pulled it and I had to rest it and wait for it to heal. I constantly felt fobbed of, but I didn’t stop. I eventually managed to get a referral to a specialist who, after an ultrasound, 2 X-rays and an MRI discovered I have a SLAP tear from an acute trauma. I’m finally starting to get it treated. Not happy it took this long.

author: LHJ96
title: My birth story
body:
I went into labour so headed up to triage - every member of staff was amazing and so reassuring. My c-section experience was also amazing - again all staff being so amazing and reassuring especially due to my severe anxiety issues. The following day after my sons birth was as expected very difficult pain wise due to having disability that effect my mobility anyways. It's because of one day of my stay that my experience has left me unable to speak about my time in hospital. What should have been a loving and memorable moment to share, a member of staff made me doubt myself as a new mum. The previous evening, a student midwife offered to take my son during the night to let me get some rest which I appreciated so so much. Especially as one of my disability includes chronic fatigue.  
In the morning the student midwife brought my son back through and he got very upset - I still wasn’t very mobile so therefore I got very upset as it was quite distressing seeing my baby boy screaming and I couldn’t get to him. Another staff member then came over to my bed and very rudely told me that they didn’t know why I was crying, that I was very lucky that someone had him overnight and that they were going to speak to doctors as it felt like I didn’t want to care for my son. This brought on a huge panic attack for me... I asked if anyone was available to talk to me to help me calm down and was told that everyone was too busy (which I do appreciate) that I had to just get on with it. I was terrified that this person was going to suggest my baby being taken away from me. During the two hour slot for my partner to come in the same staff member returned as she wanted to talk to my partner about my mental health. My partner reiterated that due to my anxiety and fatigue I get tired and sore very easily and that the best thing for me would be to go home as I had a huge support network ready to help us. Once again this staff member repeated that they were concerned over my mental health in a room with 3 other mums and continued to ask my partner if he felt I could care for my son - he answered no purely for the fact that due to my mobility issues after having a section. Now it’s very easy to hear what each other are being told - I was mortified once again. We had an agreement that as long as I was seen doing things independently, which was very difficult for me, I would be allowed to go home. So I had to push through to do it so that this person would agree to let me home. By the end of the day they were being helpful, but the morning time was just horrible.  
I’m currently going through counseling as throughout my pregnancy I wasn’t on any anti-depressants as they made me poorly and the main subject of my counseling is my post-partum period.  
My little boy is absolutely thriving and is doing amazing. The only reason I feel ready to leave my feedback as to what happened to me is I now believe that I’ve always been a good mum. One staff member's words are irrelevant, I realise they have a duty of care however there are kinder and better ways to go about it.  
I just hope that it was just that they were having a bad day - although I had a huge support system I cried for the first two weeks of my son's life. It dampened all the memories of my hospital experience.  
I wish they had a better understanding and consideration for those with mental & physical issues.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

title: Very positive patient experience
body: My optician referred me in November, and advised me that waiting times were short, and that Spa Medica had an excellent reputation. I had a pre-op appointment in December, and a successful cataract op in January. At all times I felt safe, and was treated with courtesy and professionalism by the staff, who answered any queries that I had. The building was very clean and welcoming, drinks were offered, and I was reassured and kept fully informed on the day of my operation.

title: Excellent service on phone call
body:
I had a phone call from  a Sloan Medical Centre  doctor.

I would like to report that I received wonderful service. He was courteous, attentive, knowledgeable and patient. He listened to my concerns,  answered my questions thoroughly, and immediately arranged a prescription for me.

Please pass this on to those who run the practice.

title: Wonderful Staff
body: Had to come to Darenth A&E/UTC on 24th May to have my dislocated shoulder reset and I’ve never felt so safe and at ease. All staff in UTC and X-Ray, as well as the staff in the receptions for either were so kind, caring and accommodating given all the stress of not only the last year but also the fact that it was incredibly busy that day specifically. The two nurses that reset my shoulder made sure everything was clear and understood whilst being funny and friendly which helped alleviate my anxieties of being in hospital and the worries of the injury. The exact same sentiment was shared by the X-Ray team who continued to keep up my spirits despite the pain. Very impressed by all those that I interacted with and felt very looked after - thankyou and keep up the wonderful hard work as it’s very much appreciated!

title: Great practice, excellent doctors
body: Cannot praise enough the help and treatment I've received from this surgery recently.  Been with The Gill for a few years after a couple of bad experiences with other practices, but have only now had cause to make use of the practice. So helpful, even in these strange times, excellent treatment. Highly recommend them.

title: A very caring GP
body: I cannot praise the GP I saw today highly enough. Caring, thorough and exceptionally professional at all times, she spent time with me which was so much appreciated and made me feel that my problem was completely understood. So pleasant and patient you are lucky to have her working in your practice!

title: No problems at this practice
body: Always feel like you are important, doctors seem to listen and show extra good customer service. It would be nice one day to see a doctor face to face but totally understandable in the current circumstances

title: Excellent care
body: I have always found the care offered at UEA medical medical centre to be very good but was particularly impressed by the care I received at my recent appointment which was the first time I have visited since the start of the pandemic. As my concern required a physical examination, I was offered a face to face appointment straight away rather than an initial telephone appointment which is what I had assumed I’d be offered. On the day, the doctor who saw me was very professional and explained everything clearly. He reorganised his appointments to enable him to offer a minor surgery on the same day which was a huge relief. Was really impressed by the service offered at such challenging time. Thank you to all the staff involved.

title: Thankyou
body: My thanks to every member of the team I was involved in during my short visit yesterday. I was treated with efficiency and professionalism combined with friendliness. Given the current environment these individuals are working under they were all a credit to the hospital.

readBy.name: Lancashire Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Jules1986
title: Therapy feedback
body: I was referred to Ealing IAPT service for cbt therapy to help with my depression. I was given an assessment very quickly due to having a young baby. I was assigned a therapist called Natasha, from the first telephone appointment she put me at ease straight away, she was brilliant! Listened to my issues and taught me techniques to stop overthinking everything and feel less anxious. She was very understanding and supportive. I learned lots of good tips and techniques to help me.

title: A very delightful experience
body: I had a very good experience here, the staff is amazing. They are very polite, kind and helpful. The doctor listens to you carefully. They also did follow up about how my experience was and how can they make it better.

title: Positive experience
body:
Attended 24/05/2021 as a day patient in the Urology Department. Apart from the obvious professionalism, thoroughness and attention to detail displayed by ever member of staff I met, I will carry a lasting impression of their attitude  - attentive, kind, caring, patient, supportive....and humorous, to name just a few qualities.
For one who really doesn't care at all for hospital visits it was a very positive experience. Thank you so much, keep up the good work!

author: pelicanzq74
title: Covid Swab test
body:
I had a Covid19 swab test in preparation for an ultrasound at North Devon hospital Barnstable at the end of this week.  
Involving a 70 mile round trip from Bude. Between us my husband and I have attended 4 swab tests in last month. Involving 280 miles for the swab and hospital apps. Costing a lot of money for petrol. The staff were very efficient and the instruction and information received beforehand was excellent. I did wonder why we couldn't have test at Stratton hospital and results sent to Barnstable

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent Care in A & E Department
body:
Whilst my 80+ year old parents were visiting us from Kent for the first time since lockdown, my disabled mother had a problem with a catheter, having been advised by 111 to go to A&E to have problem rectified.
Despite a very busy department  - up to 5 hrs waiting time - the team managed to find a nurse to help and treated her with such care and professionalism - turning a potential trauma into a good experience.
Well done Bournemouth Hospital - you have our thanks and continued admiration for what you do in trying circumstances.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Dorset NHS Foundation Trust

author: Stingrae12
title: Hip Replacement
body: I had a Hip Replacement at Victoria Hospital Kirkcaldy. I had excellent care from the staff on word 10 and got out of hospital. The surgeon Mr Ballantine was very skilled.

title: Excellent practice
body: I’ve been going to this practice for almost 3 years now and have been extremely happy with all care I’ve received. I’m always able to book an appointment in a reasonable amount of time or, during COVID, received a call back within 24 hours. I’m moving out of Putney and will be extremely sad to have to move practice! Thank you!

title: Fantastic
body: Can't thank all the staff in the orthopedic services at Nottingham City hospital enough for my care due to my recent hip replacement the staff were all very kind and professional once again thank you.

title: Great and proactive and  helpful-practice
body: Well organised, safe, and friendly vaccine process held here - thanks guys for going the extra mile to make this happen.

title: very good
body: Staff are always helpful, patient and considering. I have phoned the doctors several times in the last 5 months and nothing has been too much for them to attend to even tho it looks like everythings going wrong with me there has never been any hint of Oh no, it's him again.

title: Fantastic practice
body: I have not had any trouble accessing a doctor or nurse when needed all through the pandemic. The surgery from doctors to receptionists have been extremely helpful. I have had both of my injections and cannot praise enough the efficiency and kindness at both appointments. A big thank you to everyone

author: Los Angelino
title: COVID Vaccine and Hospitals
body:
Every day we hear on the news about the outstanding vaccine roll-out in the UK but I am writing to let people know that it is not the case for everyone. My husband who is in he's 70's, is undergoing cancer treatment and so he is extremely vulnerable. He had to turn down his first offer of his 2nd vaccine due to impending cancer treatment which would have been affected by it. While he was an in-patient in the hospital he was denied the 2nd vaccine when offered a 2nd time by the GP. It was now clinically suitable but the hospital told us that they had no access to vaccine! So my husband was left vulnerable for over 4 weeks in hospital as they had no means to get one for him.  
The GP surgery thought we were being difficult but we were told we could not discharge him for a vaccine as it was too 'impractical' to re-admit him due to COVID restrictions. I don't think anyone so vulnerable should have to fight for the 2nd vaccine or stay in a hospital with COVID patients in the building without being vaccinated.  
Our experience led us to believe that patients in hospitals are being denied vaccine and left vulnerable to infection. 6 weeks after his first offer, my husband has finally had his 2nd vaccine as the nursing home would not take him without it. But the hospital had to discharge him, put him in a taxi and transport him to the GP and back to get it.  
The fact that in our experience hospitals have no vaccine feels shocking on the part of the NHS which must be affecting vulnerable patients up and down the country.

readBy.name: Sheffield Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: sagittart86
title: Mirena Removal
body: Made to feel very comfortable and at ease. The nurses were lovely and helpful with a couple of questions I had.

author: RachB
title: Treatment for mosaic verrucas
body:
My daughter was seen by Dermatologist Dr French.  
Absolutely amazing Dr. Helped with her reatment, when previously others had spent years trying to help, to no avail.  
Was seen promptly even through Covid.  
Was very understanding and gave practical help to relieve symptoms and gave a course of treatment that lasted 6 months and they were all cleared.  
A very friendly, reassuring, understanding, logical and professional Doctor.  
Thank you Dr French.

author: weezee83
title: Wonderful people
body: Went to Abroath's Minor Injuries to get some metal shards taken out of my finger and everyone was incredibly great. They made me feel more relaxed and welcomed, rather than knowing I was there to get my finger scooped out. They took the care and effort to make sure each of their patients were happy and seen to properly. Wonderful people!

author: Andreweastop
title: Vaccine
body: All staff were fantastic. Very friendly and welcoming.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: aquilaqz46
title: Didn't make eye contact
body: The majority of my care today was really good however the actual administrator of the Vaccine seemed very disengaged and didn't make eye contact once - made me feel like I was a nuisance/hinderance rather than a patient.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jean-Pierre
title: I would have preferred contact in person
body:
My GP referred me to Cardiology in Forth Valley Royal Hospital. Following this, I received a letter for a telephone appointment with a consultant Cardiologist.  
The appointment with the consultant went very well. He listened to me and also provided useful information on next steps and expectations.  
However, I would have much preferred a Near Me appointment instead of a telephone appointment but this has not been offered to me. A Near Me appointment would have been better for me as I would have felt more humanly connected (body language, eye contact), especially during this 'COVID time' where human interactions were very limited. Also, seing someone's lips helps me to understand them better as English is not my first language.

title: Worst practice
body:
Being hold on the phone for over 2 hours to get an appointment then after 2 hours I drove to the practice still on the phone to be told no appointment left today ring back in the morning 
Unbelievable!!!!

title: Great Service
body:
Attended A&E on Sunday at 22-00 hrs.
Quickly booked in and seen by senior staff nurse. Lots of tests and things. Saw the Doctor who was very reassuring. Left at 02hrs.
Lovely staff, very considerate and caring. Can’t thank them enough.

title: My GP does not bother calling me
body: I called this morning for an appointment which was for 15.00. GP called very rushed did'nt seem to care, I sent in pictures but had no response 16.30. So called again to find  they had not received  pics, even though I have text saying they did receive them. Emailed in pics again at 17.20 was told gp would call before close. Got text at 19.00 limited info and said it contained link for reassurance but she didn't even bother to add it. Waste of my day and still have concerns about my health. This practice used to be good, shocked by the lack of care, been a patient here since I was a baby.

author: jockie11
title: Unable to rearrange vaccination
body:
I cancelled an appointment that I couldn’t attend.  
I have tried several days without success since, and I’ve now gone past the 12 week window.  
I’ve complained to the health board and the Scottish govt, and it’s been a complete waste of time.  
I thought we were trying to combat COVID-19 virus spread in Scotland/UK, especially the ‘Indian’ variant. If you can’t rearrange an appointment, then people shouldn’t be told they can!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

title: Awful service & careless to respond
body:
I am pregnant with critical health condition, I tried to called them many times to book a test but the reception keep disconnected me this scenario happened 5 times. 
Finally I went there to book a test but they didn't booked me at surgery and referee me to do it on phone, I mentioned  no one answer (keep disconnecting me) but they didn't care at all.
I think NHS need to do investigate, as far as I know not only me. Langstone Way Surgery need propel shake up.
I will register to another GP.

title: Not good
body: After being on hold for 1-hour and 45 minutes to book an appointment (which I didnt get) I was greeted with an unempathetic receptionist I understand we are  in a pandemic but the receptionist don't need to be so unpleasant !!!!!!

title: Wonderful practice
body:
I'm a newly registered patient and I made my first request for an appointment this month about a chronic problem. I had a text within an hour telling me that I would be called by a Dr. the next day. The Dr was very polite and friendly; she arranged for me to have blood tests and upon receiving the results I was asked to book a follow up appointment, where the same doctor explained in detail what the plan will be. I've had problems with my previous GP surgery even getting to speak to anyone about my chronic pain and I registered here after a friend spoke very highly of the staff. I am extremely impressed and happy. I couldn't recommend them more.
Thank you!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Great practice
body: My experience with the practice especially through covid have been fantastic and the doctor takes time for you.

author: Sickntired
title: Gedling local mental health services
body:
I’ve been with this service for years, and in my opinion I feel the service has gone downhill.  
From my experience I feel the psychiatrist I saw was incompetent and other staff who have worked with me I found to be aggressive in her approach. Jumping to conclusions.  
I find there’s a pattern of CPNs giving me false promises of treatment and then a few weeks later tell me they don’t think I’m eligible. I dont feel listened to and it’s just a ticking boxes process which was admitted to me by one member of staff.  
They have over stepped their boundaries on one occasion and got away with it, when they turned up at my house unannounced last year. The conversations seems repetitive, circular and in some cases manipulative. If I don’t want to talk about certain things I dont feel they shouldn’t keep pushing.  
I hate that they end all conversations with “are you suicidal” and thinks that’s an appropriate way to conclude a call. I have found this service used to be good when a different psychiatrist was there. Past staff I found to be nicer also. I felt listened to and spoken to like a human being, and my previous doctor I felt knew when I was well and when I was not & remembered conversations we had.  
I found that previous staff used to listen and give you resources to help. And there was a period I didn’t need their help. But obviously things happen and I’m with them again, but Now it’s just a joke.  
And as for the County Crisis Team, my experience of this team is no better either, I did ring the team on one occasion, but the member of staff on the line I found to be rude and seemed a bit out of it so I ended the call.  
I’m not the type to write negative reviews, but from what I have experienced I find this service is cold. I just want to be discharged, but three weeks in, still not discharged or spoken to the manager.

title: Disgusting
body: After finally getting an appointment for my blood Test to be done, and 3 phone calls from the receptionist for them to change it, I book in on time, after 40 minutes I ask how much longer because my partner is very unwell and is waiting in the car, your next im told, 15 minutes later I que up again and ask how long, I'm told you are booked for a telephone appointment, over 1 hour and still got no where, I ended up walking out, it's disgusting, I have to wait for 8 days for my prescription and literally beg them to listen, I'm now changing my doctors after 50years, Shame on you all, no wonder patients get annoyed.

title: Rude, unprofessional and uncaring reception staff!
body: I called redgate to see if they were accepting new patients and had some questions for them. The receptionist was shockingly rude! She belittled me and chastised me for using the 111 service whilst my partner was in between registering at a new doctors and without medication. I ended the call in tears after asking why the receptionist was being so rude to me when I was looking for help and support. I had to end the call as I was so upset....my partner called back to ask to speak to the practice manager to which the rude receptionist refused! We asked for complaints details and have checked these on their website before continuing with a formal complaint. Someone could be calling with mental health issues like myself and the way I was spoken to really upset me when I called asking for advise and was polite and thankful. Shame on you redgate! Please get rid of that awful woman and do right by your patients and potential patients. This should not be tolerated.

title: What does one have to do to contact the surgery?
body: I phoned the surgery every day for two weeks, without getting through, and tried the messaging system, which seems to have been disabled by the surgery.  Therefore, I wrote a letter explaining my husband's medical problems, which I personally delivered to the surgery.  The receptionist asked me what was in the letter and I told her it was a request for an appointment or a call-back.  I was told I could not obtain an appointment by this method and would have to phone.  I explained I had been phoning for two weeks.  'You'll just have to try again tomorrow', she said, 'Or, you can go to the Drop-in Centre or phone 111.'  At this point, I made the rather silly comment, 'someone could die while they are trying to contact the surgery'.   She replied, 'Well, if it was an emergency, you'd ring 999'.   I told her it was not a life-or-death situation but my husband needed GP care.  I asked the receptionist if she was going to pass my letter to a clinician or chuck it in the bin.  The receptionist just went into "broken record mode" -  'You'll have to keep phoning or go to the Walk-in Centre', so I really do  not know whether my letter will reach someone who can help my husband.  At this point, I gave up and went home.  I will try to phone again tomorrow but I do not hold out much hope.  Usually, I have always been the first to defend the NHS but this is becoming increasingly difficult.  It seems unless you have Covid symptoms, the NHS (or maybe it is just this particular surgery) does not want to know.  My husband's health has not reached a crisis that would justify a 999 call but he is very unwell and needs medical attention, which seems impossible to acquire these days.  I really despair!   I am not angry with the receptionist, who was just doing her job.  However, Primary Care in the UK seems to be non-existent.  I am angry with a system that does not allow the patient to have contact with a clinician when they need it.  Actually, on reflection, I shall be very angry with that receptionist if she does not pass my letter to a clinician.  I do not think phoning 111 and being told to attend A&E is the correct solution.  My husband needs ongoing care from his GP but this seems impossible to obtain.   I would very much appreciate a reply to my comments from the surgery but I won't hold my breath as it seems that is not something they do.  Actually, do they even read the comments?  I do appreciate that these are very difficult times because of Covid but should Primary Care just abandon their patients?

author: Jean-Pierre
title: Unsure of how to get my results
body:
My GP referred me to Cardiology in Forth Valley Royal Hospital. Then I have had an telephone appointment with a consultant Cardiologist who suggested to organise an Echocardiogram and a Scan. I have had both done but no results have been communicated to me and I have no idea when this will be done and how. On the leaflet sent to me in preparation for the scan it is only mentioned 'we will send the results to the Doctor who asked for your scan'.  
The care I received on the day by the staff was wonderful, especially from the Nurses who looked after me and made sure I was ok all the way through. They were so kind and helpful, really heart warming. What was not good is not being told anything regarding my results. The consultant cardiologist was in the Scan room and stood next to me for a few minutes while I was being placed on the machine but I have no idea why they were there as this was not explained to me. Back in the ward, I've asked about how and when the results would be communicated to me but the answer was vague and I only understood that it would take some time i.e. maybe a few weeks.  
This makes me feel stressed. I have been suffering for a year from the condition for which these investigations are being done and not having visibility on how and when the results will be communicated to me adds to the anxiety. I can only assume that if the Echo and/or the Scan revealed something serious then I would have been told. But that is only an assumption from myself and I wish someone from the team could have officially communicate something to me on the day. Instead, I just left the Hospital with no further information on my health and the investigations done that day. And as of today, I still have no idea when I will contacted about my results.

title: Shambolic verging on incompetent
body:
My wife (a cancer patient) called The Colliery Practice at 8:30 am, when she finally got through after 9 o'clock she was referred to local pharmacist and told to expect a call from them within 3 hours. 4 hours later she called the Colliery Practice again (45 mins wait) to ask why she had not received her referral call, they said "just turn up at the Pharmacist". On arrival at the Pharmacists she was told she should never be referred to them because of her existing medical condition and that she needed to see her doctor, she asked why she was referred if the practice know she can not be seen by the Pharmacist, she was told "they just send everyone, most people we can't help". My wife walked from the Pharmacists to the doctors and spoke to the receptionist only to be told that even though she was standing right there in front of the computer she could not book my wife in for an appointment because she needed to phone. My wife returned home and joined the call que at number 18. When the call was answered she asked why it had taken 6 hours for her to finally reach the stage where she could book an appointment, she was told they hadn't realised she was a cancer patient even though this is clear on her records and her details were taken during the original call. My wife was told "we don't have time to look at the computer".

This is a shambolic Practice, with pharmacist consultations apparently being used to deflect/delay patients regardless of the severity of there existing medical conditions. I find the implication that the receptionist or call handler (apparently acting as a gate keeper to NHS medical services) would not have time to do their job properly (but stage 4 cancer patients have all the time in the world) utterly disgusting. The inadequacy of the Colliery Practice appointment system and its application resulted in the wasted time of my wife, the Pharmacists, and the Practices own staff.  This is just the last example of the Colliery Practices incompetence with the only successful or satisfactory appointment my wife has ever had was with a locum doctor. If their was a single doctors practice in the area taking on patients we would leave.

title: Extremely unprofessional
body: At least one hours wait before the call is answered! Once the call has been answered the reception staff are so rude and unprofessional, they speak to you in a very unfriendly manner. The actual doctors are not too bad but the receptionist’s really let this practice down!

title: Can't make an appointment
body: I have requested test for my nine year old daughter who is disable ,the reception said they will send text to come and collect the form to do all day I was waiting , haven't heard from them ,agin I called the next day they said they will text again I was wait no response , really annoying , just want to change my GP ,making appointment is very hard every time I call no appointment is available even I call on time and wit ages in que still no luck ,very rough system of making appointment.

title: Well looked after
body: I came to a&e in immense pain due to a knee injury. From checking in to being assessed and moved to Portland ward for a procedure I was treated with great care and understanding. Can't complain about being in there all day, we're dealing with a pandemic and all the staff were marvellous! Everything was explained to me and I left feeling reassured and in a lot less pain. I'm now recovering at home and cannot thank enough everyone that helped me.

readBy.name: Chesterfield Royal Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Not fit for purpose. Absolutely shocking levels…
body: A care coordinator should at the very least make attempts to contact a referral as soon as is possible and NOT wait for the patient to contact the centre first. Also, many people will not answer with-held numbers as it could be a cold call. This is a shockingly bad level of care when compared to may 2017 when not only had I spoken to but also been visited at home by the care coordinator assigned back then. Makes me feel that I am not going receive the treatment that I should have received in hospital. Oxleas is failing it's mental health patients badly

title: Awful Customer service
body:
I arrived for my xray 15 minutes early, I booked a taxi and didn't know what the traffic was like, bearing in mind we've loads of visitors down and we've also got the police sealing the drains in preparation for the G7 summit.
I was told off for coming early for my appointment and for interrupting the lady's lunch break, I explained my travel problems but was still reprimanded.
Quite upsetting behaviour when you're ill I think,  not very caring or understanding

title: Service has been poor lately, staff not as helpful
body: Service has been poor lately, staff not as helpful or straight forward as they once were. Been struggling with trying to get a health issue resolved for months

title: The worst practice in Plymouth.
body:
This is a company and the worst of them. They generally don’t care about what you say on their forms and also “ghost” you and say they’ve tried to call you. I recently had a telephone appointment not come through and I got a text telling me they “tried to call me” even though my phone was set to allow all calls through. I then called the GP to make sure they had my number correct, which they did, and they had the audacity to say “oh he’s out here he’s tried to call” in a mean tone. If your phone system is faulty, fix it. Don’t blame a bad system knowing it’s not working and then do nothing about it. 

I also got a referred through to a service no longer being offered in my area for insomnia after being fobbed off for that too. A lot of my friends grew up in plympton and we all agree that this GP has dramatically gone down hill in the last 10 years. Some of these issues could land you in A&E like I did. 

Honestly try a different GP.

title: Disgusting service
body:
Please explain to me how a txt message stating that you have sent a prescription of an inhaler to a pharmacy for my children (who don't have asthma) for a persistent new cough they have had for the past 5/6 days. With no diagnosis, no explanation of why you have not prescribed antibiotics, no actual doctor speaking to me, to find out that we had been already trying an inhaler (based on a previous cough my daughter had had and been prescribed, that also didn't work), no information as to if they should take a PCR test (was informed that the lateral flow test they took was useless by your nurse and she would find out if they needed a PCR).
Then after receiving the disgusting text message, when phoning back for some clarification, being told by your receptionist (on the phone) that we had been given a consultation and a "decision had been made by the doctor on the course of action" when asked what the decision was, I was told that no one could talk to me about it. And that I had already had my time to ask during the consultation (I never even spoke to the doctor on the phone, nor did I receive any information other than a text saying a prescription was sent to tesco for both children) she refused to provide me with any information from my 8 years old sons and 6 year old daughter records about the issue as well as refused to put me onto a manager or someone who could provide me with the information.. 
Your surgery is an absolute disgrace.. Your care only about the money you get not care of the patient.

title: Very poor practice
body: I have to phone up nearly 45 times on two different mobiles at the same time to get an appointment they do not cater for people that work I had a phone call from a doctor and he explained that I needed to book an appointment I phoned up the next day to try and book and they refuse to book it because the doctor didn't put it on the notes their communication is very poor to I have two young children that I refused to go to the surgery and they stay with the mother surgery also they can be quite rude on the front desk and very unhelpful why don't they bring in phone call queuing system instead of trying to ring 1000 times to get an appointment and they're always quick enough to palm you off with the nurses that actually don't know what they're doing and that have missed diagnosed me more than once the NHS really need to do something about this practice plus the village is getting bigger definitely the Care Quality Commission should get involved

title: Miss information
body: Was told to go to the surgery at 7am this morning by a receptionist  to make an appointment only to find out the surgery dosnt open till 8 o'clock and the receptionist denied point blank shed said  this

title: Disgraceful
body: A care coordinator that you can't get hold of, reluctant to even bother to try and contact you... Seems like they don't care.

title: Appalling.
body:
Trying to get through on the phone is a marathon. Often takes longer than 20 minutes.
On answering you're greeted by someone growling "Surgery". No niceties or humanity. 
Had more than one "callback" booked where they haven't called.
Appointment? What's that? Rare as Hens teeth! They need to close this place down and build something useful there.

author: KylahF21
title: Therapy with Inclusion Thurrock
body:
After hitting rock bottom last year, I contacted Inclusion Thurrock. I was nervous and had reservations that therapy could even help me. Believe me, I felt that I did not want to live on this earth any more.  
The initial assessment was done with compassion and the wait to get to therapy was around 2-3mths.  
My therapist Maame was amazing. She helped me to break down all of my feelings,, emotions and habits so I could see the damage my negative thinking and negative learnt behaviour from childhood was impacting on my life.  
Each week has been both difficult and enlightening as I have become more aware of myself - and this means I am now conscious of where my thoughts are taking me - which in turn affects my behaviours.  
Therapy for me is ongoing. I am not ‘cured’ (something at the start I thought I would be) but I am ‘equipped’ - which is exactly where I need to be. I am learning to ‘go with the flow’ of life and not resisting it. I am learning the only person I have control over is me - and as such, I do not have to be negative. I do have a lot of positive qualities I have overlooked and taken for granted.  
I have just finished - today in fact - my sessions with Maame and whilst i am nervous that I am ‘now on my own’ as such, she has helped me to have faith in myself and my abilities to continue growing in myself.  
I have had ups and downs throughout my therapy and I am not critical to myself about them as this is what will and does happen. My negative view of myself had been there for years, so it will not change overnight, but with my awareness and the tools I gained in my sessions, I can ‘accept and activate positive change for me’.  
I can only sincerely thank Maame and everyone at Inclusion Thurrock for helping me to get to love and accept me.  
If you feel like you can no longer cope, please do give therapy a try when you are ready to. It does take work. It means opening up to you - to your own self - but you will find you are not alone and you don’t have to live in the pain you are currently in.  
I have a long journey still in front of me, but I have knowledge of all the things I can do and use to help it be a productive and positive one for me.

author: NSMgz48
title: Staff were brilliant
body: All NHS staff were brilliant before and after my sons operation in May. The only thing was we were in ward 1A then few hours after my sons operation we had to move wards to 1E. I thought this was not good especially for infection control plus to be told short staffed that why ward was to close. I couldn't thank all staff enough they are rushed off their feet and do a brilliant job to the best they can under pressure and still make sure I was ok and my son even going out there way to make myself toast and coffee even when there shift had finished... Royal hospital for children is brilliant 👏

author: cobraing1
title: Unhappy with service
body:
Went to this service previously and I didn't find it helpful, now they have changed there name I still feel like the service is not good. I rang my doctors they told me to use the same service and to give them a chance. I contacted them and discussed with them, I was only rang up once and was advised to cut down.  
They are no good, rang doctors, months ago I told them I don't want to use this service again, but they assured me they have changed and are better, but again I was only rang me up twice and that was only because I chased them up, I'm at my wit's end, I couldn't recommend this service.

author: polarisgy94
title: Did not make me feel at ease
body: It started off very pleasant with lovely staff until it came to the injection itself. The staff member felt the need to inform me how they didn't want to be there and how covid was a shambles, how they would rather be out in the sun than stuck in the SSE arena, before saying what arm and literally stabbing it in, resulting in me coming home covered in blood and already a very painful arm. I cannot fault the SSE Arena or any other member of the fantastic staff or the rollout of the vaccine. But already being slightly anxious, this member of staff certainly did not make me feel at ease. So I apologise for being an inconvenience when you would rather be out in the sun. You might want to have a look at this bedside manner. I presume that they are being paid and aren't there for the love of it.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Kirstycotton
title: Getting vaccine
body: Super fast, efficient, well looked after, friendly staff. Fantastic job from start to finish

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: guidekc83
title: Abdominal pain
body: Had questions asked, examination done very friendly made me feel comfortable and relaxed

author: mallonlin
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: My stay
body: The nurses and staff are extremley caring and attentive. Dr.Wiebald and Dr Fread were attentive and informative. All the Staff on ward 2 made me feel comfortable and safe during my stay.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: creativecookie101
title: Covid-19 vaccination
body:
Have now received both doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine against Covid-19 and want to say how appreciative I am of the professional, kind and effective service from the NHS. I received my 1st dose before the report was made about this vaccine type and additional risks associated with my particular age group, but the service, especially on Day2 could not be faulted at all.  
All information was clear, given with care and support and with plenty opportunity for questions. The setup of the vaccination centre was brilliantly done to ensure safety and distance. Was in and out in no time at all. Thank you to our beloved NHS nurses, staff and all other key workers who have made this rollout possible and effective. You don't get enough thanks and appropriate care back and if this feedback even makes a very small change, I'm happy to do that. If I could give you more resources and a pay-rise myself, I would do that but I urge our Government to fight as strongly for our NHS as the NHS has for the people under its care during this devastating pandemic.

author: mallonlin
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The care I received
body:
during my stay in ward 2 in SWAH I've had excellent care, the nurses are very understanding wit your every need.  
This group on ward 2 makes me feel very welcome as it has become my second home.  
The care, support, kindness and patience the nurses have giving me is absolutely fantastic

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Marpm83
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Grateful to community palliative care teams
body:
The St Luke's [Harrow community] palliative care teams were a real life saver for us. The situation with my father (step) was at a crisis point where his health had deteriorated very rapidly throwing our lives into chaos.  
Hilary came and did an assessment and got help organised really quickly. She was kind, professional and efficient: just what we needed at this really difficult moment.  
The staff from the St Luke's Palliative helpline were professional, provided timely responses to our queries and managed care effectively in conjunction with other services.  
We will always be grateful to St Luke's.

author: Aps87
title: Vaccine time!
body:
Went for my second covid vaccine in Ballymena, it is a very organised process, quick and easy!  
I am writing because I particularly want to mention a fabulous volunteer who was friendly, knowledgable and put your mind at ease.... Gerry, thank you.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust
